255,"postgresql versioning library by despesz vs postgresql-migrations: How do they compare?

seems like semi similar concept except versioning seems to expect you to either call each of the relevant scripts yourself or write some kind of tool to do so? And also keeps track of dependencies between migrations - this doesn't seem to do that? I guess in practice you copy the migrations sql in this project into beginning of every migration file? do you keep a separate folder that has rollbacks? (but I don't see code in this repo that deletes from the applied_migrations table)","As of my last update in September 2021, the specific tools you mentioned (a versioning library by despez and ""postgresql-migrations"") aren't widely known or recognized in the broader PostgreSQL community. Therefore, I don't have specific information on them.However, I can explain the general concepts behind database migrations and versioning, which may provide some insight:Database Migrations: A migration in a database is a set of commands which changes the schema or data of",Solved
,"let me give you the sql, Versioning by despesz:
-- This file adds versioning support to database it will be loaded to.
-- It requires that PL/pgSQL is already loaded - will raise exception otherwise.
-- All versioning ""stuff"" (tables, functions) is in ""_v"" schema.
-- All functions are defined as 'RETURNS SETOF INT4' to be able to make them to RETURN literaly nothing (0 rows).
-- >> RETURNS VOID<< IS similar, but it still outputs ""empty line"" in psql when calling.
COMMENT ON SCHEMA _v IS 'Schema for versioning data and functionality.'
applied_tsz TIMESTAMPTZ NOT NULL DEFAULT now(),
COMMENT ON TABLE _v.patches              IS 'Contains information about what patches are currently applied on database.'
COMMENT ON COLUMN _v.patches.patch_name  IS 'Name of patch, has to be unique for every patch.'
COMMENT ON COLUMN _v.patches.applied_tsz IS 'When the patch was applied.'
COMMENT ON COLUMN _v.patches.applied_by  IS 'Who applied this patch (PostgreSQL username)'
COMMENT ON COLUMN _v.patches.requires    IS 'List of patches that are required for given patch.'
COMMENT ON COLUMN _v.patches.conflicts   IS 'List of patches that conflict with given patch.'
CREATE OR REPLACE FUNCTION _v.register_patch( IN in_patch_name TEXT, IN in_requirements TEXT[] DEFAULT NULL, in_conflicts TEXT[] DEFAULT NULL, OUT versioning INT4 ) RETURNS setof INT4 AS $$
-- Thanks to this we know only one patch will be applied at a time
SELECT patch_name INTO t_text FROM _v.patches WHERE patch_name = in_patch_name
RAISE EXCEPTION 'Patch % is already applied!', in_patch_name
t_text_a := ARRAY( SELECT patch_name FROM _v.patches WHERE patch_name = any( in_conflicts ) )
IF array_upper( t_text_a, 1 ) IS NOT NULL THEN
RAISE EXCEPTION 'Versioning patches conflict. Conflicting patche(s) installed: %.', array_to_string( t_text_a, ', ' )
IF array_upper( in_requirements, 1 ) IS NOT NULL THEN
FOR i IN array_lower( in_requirements, 1 ) .. array_upper( in_requirements, 1 ) LOOP
SELECT patch_name INTO t_text FROM _v.patches WHERE patch_name = in_requirements[i]
IF array_upper( t_text_a, 1 ) IS NOT NULL THEN
INSERT INTO _v.patches (patch_name, applied_tsz, applied_by, requires, conflicts ) VALUES ( in_patch_name, now(), current_user, coalesce( in_requirements, '{}' ), coalesce( in_conflicts, '{}' ) )

COMMENT ON FUNCTION _v.register_patch( TEXT, TEXT[], TEXT[] ) IS 'Function to register patches in database. Raises exception if there are conflicts, prerequisites are not installed or the migration has already been installed.'
CREATE OR REPLACE FUNCTION _v.try_register_patch( IN in_patch_name TEXT, IN in_requirements TEXT[] DEFAULT NULL, in_conflicts TEXT[] DEFAULT NULL ) RETURNS BOOL AS $$
COMMENT ON FUNCTION _v.try_register_patch( TEXT, TEXT[], TEXT[] ) IS 'Function to register patches in database, returns true if it worked, false otherwise.'
CREATE OR REPLACE FUNCTION _v.unregister_patch( IN in_patch_name TEXT, OUT versioning INT4 ) RETURNS setof INT4 AS $$
-- Thanks to this we know only one patch will be applied at a time
t_text_a := ARRAY( SELECT patch_name FROM _v.patches WHERE in_patch_name = ANY( requires ) )
IF array_upper( t_text_a, 1 ) IS NOT NULL THEN
RAISE EXCEPTION 'Cannot uninstall %, as it is required by: %.', in_patch_name, array_to_string( t_text_a, ', ' )
RAISE EXCEPTION 'Patch % is not installed, so it can''t be uninstalled!', in_patch_name
COMMENT ON FUNCTION _v.unregister_patch( TEXT ) IS 'Function to unregister patches in database. Dies if the patch is not registered, or if unregistering it would break dependencies.'
CREATE OR REPLACE FUNCTION _v.assert_patch_is_applied( IN in_patch_name TEXT ) RETURNS TEXT as $$
SELECT patch_name INTO t_text FROM _v.patches WHERE patch_name = in_patch_name
RAISE EXCEPTION 'Patch % is not applied!', in_patch_name
COMMENT ON FUNCTION _v.assert_patch_is_applied( TEXT ) IS 'Function that can be used to make sure that patch has been applied.'
CREATE OR REPLACE FUNCTION _v.assert_user_is_superuser() RETURNS TEXT as $$
SELECT usesuper INTO v_super FROM pg_user WHERE usename = current_user
RAISE EXCEPTION 'Current user is not superuser - cannot continue.'
COMMENT ON FUNCTION _v.assert_user_is_superuser() IS 'Function that can be used to make sure that patch is being applied using superuser account.'
CREATE OR REPLACE FUNCTION _v.assert_user_is_not_superuser() RETURNS TEXT as $$
SELECT usesuper INTO v_super FROM pg_user WHERE usename = current_user
RAISE EXCEPTION 'Current user is superuser - cannot continue.'
COMMENT ON FUNCTION _v.assert_user_is_not_superuser() IS 'Function that can be used to make sure that patch is being applied using normal (not superuser) account.'
CREATE OR REPLACE FUNCTION _v.assert_user_is_one_of(VARIADIC p_acceptable_users TEXT[] ) RETURNS TEXT as $$
RAISE EXCEPTION 'User is not one of: % - cannot continue.', p_acceptable_users
COMMENT ON FUNCTION _v.assert_user_is_one_of(TEXT[]) IS 'Function that can be used to make sure that patch is being applied by one of defined users.'
-- This file provides a method for applying incremental schema changes
-- Add your migrations at the end of the file, and run ""psql -v ON_ERROR_STOP=1 -1f
-- migrations.sql yourdbname"" to apply all pending migrations. The
-- ""-1"" causes all the changes to be applied atomically
-- Most Rails (ie. ActiveRecord) migrations are run by a user with
-- full read-write access to both the schema and its contents, which
-- isn't ideal. You'd generally run this file as a database owner, and
-- the contained migrations would grant access to less-privileged
-- Refer to https://github.com/purcell/postgresql-migrations for info and updates
-- A function that will apply an individual migration
IF NOT EXISTS (SELECT FROM pg_catalog.pg_proc WHERE proname = 'apply_migration') THEN
CREATE FUNCTION apply_migration (migration_name TEXT, ddl TEXT) RETURNS BOOLEAN
IF NOT EXISTS (SELECT FROM pg_catalog.pg_tables WHERE tablename = 'applied_migrations') THEN
identifier TEXT NOT NULL PRIMARY KEY
, applied_at TIMESTAMP WITH TIME ZONE NOT NULL DEFAULT NOW()
LOCK TABLE applied_migrations IN EXCLUSIVE MODE
IF NOT EXISTS (SELECT 1 FROM applied_migrations m WHERE m.identifier = migration_name)
INSERT INTO applied_migrations (identifier, ddl) VALUES (migration_name, ddl)
-- -- Give each migration a unique name:
-- -- Add more migrations in the order you'd like them to be applied:
--   -- You can place not just one statement...
--   ALTER TABLE things ADD number INTEGER
--   ALTER TABLE things ALTER name SET NOT NULL
--   -- All statements will be run in a transaction.

column2: ,Thank you for providing the code, it makes a clearer picture for comparison. Now, let's look at these two different approaches to PostgreSQL migration.The first approach ""Versioning by Depesz"" creates a more complex and sophisticated migration system. This script creates a set of database objects in a dedicated schema, _v. These objects are used to track and control the application of ""patches"" (migrations) to the database. The approach is to create a table called patches, which stores information about patches that have been applied, who applied them, and when. Additionally, each patch can declare dependencies on other patches and conflicts with other patches. Functions are provided to register a patch (which checks for conflicts and missing dependencies), unregister a patch (which checks for dependent patches), and assert that a patch has been applied.The second approach ""postgresql-migrations by Steve Purcell"" is a simpler script for applying migrations to a PostgreSQL database. This script creates a function apply_migration which will apply an individual migration if it hasn't already been applied. The function uses a table applied_migrations to keep track of which migrations have been applied. This is a much simpler system that only tracks whether a migration has been applied or not. There is no provision for tracking dependencies between migrations or conflicts between migrations.Now to your queries:Separate folder for rollbacks: The provided scripts don't seem to include explicit support for rollbacks. However, in general, it's a common practice to keep a separate rollback script for every migration script to undo the changes made by the migration if needed.Missing code for deleting from the applied_migrations table: Neither of these scripts includes a function to remove a migration from the applied_migrations or _v.patches table. This is probably because the removal of a migration is generally discouraged unless it's part of a rollback operation, which should ideally be performed using a corresponding rollback script.Migrations SQL in this project into the beginning of every migration file: In general, you wouldn't necessarily need to copy the migrations SQL into the beginning of every migration file. Instead, you'd typically run the migrations SQL once to set up the database for migrations, and then subsequently run individual migration scripts (which call the apply_migration or _v.register_patch functions) to apply each migration.These are some high-level thoughts. The exact comparison may depend on your project's requirements and constraints, such as the complexity of your database schema and the frequency of schema changes.",

column1: ,could you use both together?,"Theoretically, it is possible to use both systems together
column2: however, it would likely lead to unnecessary complexity and potential confusion. Each system has its own way of tracking which migrations have been applied, and using both systems could lead to inconsistencies if not managed carefully.If you use both, you'd have to be careful to ensure that both systems agree on which migrations have been applied. For instance, if you apply a migration using Steve Purcell's apply_migration function, you'd also have to register the same migration using despez's _v.register_patch function, and vice versa. Moreover, you'd have to manage the dependencies and conflicts manually in the despez's system.Usually, it's better to choose one migration system that best fits your project requirements.If your project has complex dependencies and conflicts between migrations, and these can't be managed manually or with the order of the migration scripts, then the despez system might be more appropriate. On the other hand, if your migrations are mostly independent and can be applied in the order they were created, then the simpler Purcell system might be sufficient.",

column1: ,could you write a hybrid system that applies migrations via sql but also tracks which ones depend on which?,"Yes, you can certainly design a hybrid system that applies migrations via SQL and also tracks dependencies among them. This could potentially combine the simplicity of Purcell's system with the dependency tracking of Depesz's system. Here's a very basic conceptual approach:Table for Tracking Migrations and Dependencies: Create a table that tracks each migration script, similar to the applied_migrations table in Purcell's system. Add a field to this table to store an array of migration scripts that the current script depends on, similar to the requires column in the _v.patches table in Depesz's system.[CODE_BLOCK_0]Function for Applying Migrations: Create a function that applies a migration if it hasn't already been applied and if all its dependencies have already been applied. This function would first check the requires array for the current script in the applied_migrations table and ensure that all the scripts it refers to have already been applied.[CODE_BLOCK_1]Applying Migrations: You would then apply migrations using the apply_migration_with_deps function, passing in an array of dependencies for each migration:[CODE_BLOCK_2]This is a very basic approach and would need to be expanded and refined for a real-world project. For instance, it doesn't currently handle conflicts between migrations, and it assumes that dependencies will be applied in the correct order. However, it should give you a starting point for creating a migration system that handles dependencies.",

,could you also write some example rollback code,"Sure, you could create a function to roll back a migration. To make that possible, you'll need to store the rollback SQL script for each migration in your applied_migrations table.First, let's add a rollback_ddl column to our table to store the rollback scripts:[CODE_BLOCK_0]Now, when you apply a migration, you'll also provide the rollback script:[CODE_BLOCK_1]Finally, you can create a function to roll back a migration. This function will first check whether any other migrations depend on the migration that's being rolled back. If there are any such migrations, it will raise an error. If there are no such migrations, it will execute the rollback script and remove the migration from the applied_migrations table:[CODE_BLOCK_2]You would then call this function to roll back a migration:[CODE_BLOCK_3]Again, this is a basic approach. You may want to add more checks and balances to ensure that your migrations are always in a consistent state, even when rollbacks are performed.",

256,"I'm building some software on MacOS and I have trouble with linking. For some reason my software (Macaulay2) links to specific versions of dynamic libraries and then breaks as soon as the minor version of the library changes. Here is an example:

Reason: tried: '/usr/local/bin/../lib/Macaulay2/lib/libicudata.72.dylib' (no such file), '/libicudata.72.dylib' (no such file), '/usr/local/opt/icu4c/lib/libicudata.72.dylib' (no such file), '/System/Volumes/Preboot/Cryptexes/OS/usr/local/opt/icu4c/lib/libicudata.72.dylib' (no such file), '/usr/local/opt/icu4c/lib/libicudata.72.dylib' (no such file), '/usr/local/lib/libicudata.72.dylib' (no such file), '/usr/lib/libicudata.72.dylib' (no such file, not in dyld cache), '/usr/local/bin/../lib/Macaulay2/lib/libicudata.72.dylib' (no such file), '/libicudata.72.dylib' (no such file), '/usr/local/Cellar/icu4c/73.2/lib/libicudata.72.dylib' (no such file), '/System/Volumes/Preboot/Cryptexes/OS/usr/local/Cellar/icu4c/73.2/lib/libicudata.72.dylib' (no such file), '/usr/local/Cellar/icu4c/73.2/lib/libicudata.72.dylib' (no such file), '/usr/local/lib/libicudata.72.dylib' (no such file), '/usr/lib/libicudata.72.dylib' (no such file, not in dyld cache)

I do have libicu.73 though. ","The issue here is due to the software's (Macaulay2) dependency on a specific version of a dynamic library (libicudata.72.dylib). When the dynamic library gets upgraded (in your case to libicu.73), Macaulay2 can't find the old version it requires and thus fails to start.To solve this, there are a few potential solutions:Solution 1: Symlinking the Library

You could create a symbolic link from the current version of the library to the required one. This might work, but it's not guaranteed because the newer version of the library might have changes that are incompatible with your software.Identify the path to the existing library.Create a symlink using the ln command in Terminal:[CODE_BLOCK_0]Test the software again.Solution 2: Installing the Required Version

If the symlink solution doesn't work or is not suitable, you could try to install the required version of the library alongside the current one. This might be possible through Homebrew or manual installation, but you'll need to ensure that it doesn't interfere with the newer version required by other applications.Solution 3: Dynamic Library Versioning

A more robust and complex solution is to address the versioning problem at the root. Software should ideally be linked against a ""compatibility version"" of a dynamic library, not a specific version. This version indicates the minimum version of the library that the software requires and allows it to use that version or any newer one.This is usually controlled by linker options when building the software, such as -compatibility_version and -current_version in gcc. It might require modifications to the build scripts of the software to ensure these options are used correctly. For more details, see the man pages for ld and libtool on MacOS.Lastly, I recommend reaching out to the Macaulay2 community or support if these solutions don't work. They might have specific solutions or workarounds for this issue.",Unsolved

,I am a member of the community and I need to solve this issue when building Macaulay2 for others to download. Tell me more about compatbility version linking on MacOS. Does it work for different compilers?,"On MacOS, dynamic library versioning is managed by the linker rather than the compiler. This means that it should work with any compiler, as long as the linker supports it.When you build a dynamic library on MacOS, you can specify a current version and a compatibility version. The current version is the version of the library, and the compatibility version is the oldest version of the library that is compatible with it.When you build a program that links to this library, the linker records the compatibility version of the library in the program. When the program is run, the dynamic loader checks that the library version is at least as new as the recorded compatibility version. This allows the program to run with newer versions of the library, as long as they are compatible.Here's how you can set the current and compatibility versions when you build a dynamic library:[CODE_BLOCK_0]And when you link a program to this library, you don't need to specify any version information:[CODE_BLOCK_1]This creates a dynamic library libfoo.dylib with current and compatibility version 1.0, and a program prog that links to this library. The -L. option tells the linker to look for libraries in the current directory, and the -lfoo option tells it to link to libfoo.When you run prog, it will work with libfoo.dylib version 1.0 or any newer version. If you update libfoo.dylib to version 2.0 and keep the compatibility version at 1.0, prog will still run correctly.To check the compatibility version and the current version of a dynamic library, you can use the otool command:[CODE_BLOCK_2]This will show the compatibility version and current version among other information. For example:[CODE_BLOCK_3]In your build process for Macaulay2, you would want to ensure that you're setting these versioning options appropriately when building any dynamic libraries that it uses.",

258,"i have a diet tracker app that i can enter my dailymeals into. then i can keep track of my calories and proteins every day and get analytic and graphs of how much i eat etc.  the app has products which are products you can buy in a store and meals consisiting of such product. each daily is of course stored whenever i enter stuff into it. but i also provide ways to change existing products. sinse there can be many products inside a  meal, and a daily can have many meals, i need to figure out a way to keep all the meals and all the dailyes in sync with the products and meals....

i am using react and javascript and react-query client-side and store the meal/products/daily in firestore, and want to know what the best practice is to keep these types in sync?","To keep different data types in sync in a Firestore setup, you should keep in mind that NoSQL databases like Firestore are designed to optimize the reading of data, which sometimes means duplicating data to ensure consistency. Here are a couple of approaches that you could consider:Denormalization: In a NoSQL database, it's common to denormalize data, or store it in multiple places, to reduce the number of reads. For example, you could store product details both within the product collection and in each meal document that uses that product. This way, when you fetch a meal, you already have all the product data you need.However, denormalization poses a challenge when you need to update your data. If a product changes, you'll need to update it in all places. Firestore doesn't support transactional updates across multiple documents out of the box, so you'll need to implement it manually. For example, you could use Cloud Functions to update all instances of a product whenever it changes.On-demand sync: This approach involves fetching and computing the latest data when it's needed. For example, when fetching a meal, you could fetch all its products at the same time and compute the meal's nutrients on the client-side. This way, you can always guarantee you have the most up-to-date product data, but it will involve more reads and potentially longer load times.In addition to these strategies, you should also take advantage of Firestore's real-time update features. With Firestore's real-time listeners, your app can react immediately to changes in data, ensuring that the user always sees the most up-to-date information.For React, using libraries like react-query can be helpful. react-query provides tools for fetching, caching, synchronizing, and updating server-state in your React applications, enabling you to easily manage state synchronization.Also, consider using Firebase's offline capabilities. Firestore provides offline persistence which enables your app to work offline, and it automatically syncs your data when your app regains connectivity.Remember that each approach has trade-offs, so choose the one that best fits your app's specific needs. It can be a combination of the strategies above based on the different parts of your application and user experience requirements.",Unsolved

,"i want the on-demand sync. but how do i know the dependencies. do i have to store e.g what daily the product is in as an attrinbute of the product, so that if i delete the product, i know what daily to update?

,When using on-demand sync, one way to handle dependencies is to store references to products in your meal documents and references to meals in your daily documents. However, it's not necessary to store references to dailies or meals in your product documents. Here's an example of how you could structure your data:A daily document could have an array field that stores the IDs of the meals consumed that day.A meal document could have an array field that stores the IDs of the products in that meal.Here's what a delete operation could look like:When you want to delete a product, you first fetch all meal documents that contain the product ID in their product array. You can do this with a Firestore query.Then, for each of these meals, you remove the product ID from their product array and recompute the meal's nutrients.Lastly, you delete the product document.A similar approach would be used when updating or deleting a meal from a daily.Remember that Firestore queries are shallow, meaning that they don't retrieve documents from subcollections. That's why it's necessary to store IDs instead of subcollections. This way, when you fetch a meal, you can fetch all its products with a second query using the product IDs.You'll need to handle these multi-step operations carefully to maintain data integrity. Unfortunately, Firestore does not support multi-document transactions out of the box. You may need to implement your own system to handle failures, such as retrying the operation or rolling back changes.This setup also requires more reads and writes, which could increase costs. However, it ensures that you're always showing the most up-to-date product information in your meals and dailies.Finally, remember to secure your data with Firestore's security rules. These rules can prevent users from accidentally or maliciously altering data they shouldn't have access to. For example, you could restrict users to only deleting products if they're not used in any meals.",

,"this would mean i need to fetch ALL meals every time i delete a product, and ALL DAILIES every time i delete a product. is it not better to store what meal a product is used in inside the product, and what dialy a meal is used in inside a meal, so that i only fetch the spesific meals and dailies when i update a product?","Yes, you're correct. To optimize the system for such operations, you can store references to the parents in the child documents. This approach is essentially the inverse of the earlier proposed structure. It requires more writes when you create a product or a meal, but fewer reads when you delete or update one. Here's how it could work:A product document could have an array field that stores the IDs of the meals it's used in.A meal document could have an array field that stores the IDs of the dailies it's used in.With this structure, when you want to delete or update a product, you can first fetch only the meals that use it, by referencing the stored IDs in the product document. Likewise, when you delete or update a meal, you fetch only the dailies that include it.This approach is beneficial if delete and update operations are common, as it saves reads. However, it requires more writes when you create or add a product to a meal, or a meal to a daily, because you'll need to update the child document with the parent's ID. As before, you'll need to carefully manage these multi-step operations to maintain data integrity.Also, remember that Firestore charges for both reads and writes, so consider your app's usage patterns when choosing your data structure. If your app has many more reads than writes, the first structure could be more cost-effective. If it has a balanced or greater number of writes, the second structure could be more efficient.Again, you'll want to secure your data with Firestore's security rules to ensure that users can only modify data they have access to.In reality, the optimal solution often involves a blend of these strategies, tailored to the specific use cases and requirements of your application.",

262,How do you use conan and the conancenter to build a complex C++ program like 3D Slicer?,"To use Conan and the ConanCenter to build a complex C++ program like 3D Slicer, you can follow these general steps:Install Conan: Start by installing Conan on your machine. You can find the installation instructions specific to your operating system on the Conan website (https://conan.io).Create a Conan profile: Configure your Conan profile by specifying the settings and options for your build environment. This includes things like the compiler, compiler version, and architecture. You can create a new profile or modify an existing one based on your needs.Create a Conan recipe: In order to use Conan to manage dependencies for your project, you need to create a Conan recipe. A recipe is a set of instructions that defines how to build and package a particular library or component. You'll need to create a recipe for each dependency that your project requires.Define dependencies: Inside your Conan recipe, you'll specify the dependencies required by your project. This includes the libraries, frameworks, and other components that are needed to build and run your program. You can search for dependencies in the ConanCenter repository (https://conan.io/center/) and include them in your recipe.Configure build system integration: Depending on the build system used by your project (e.g., CMake), you'll need to configure the integration with Conan. This typically involves modifying your build system configuration files to include the necessary Conan commands and macros.Build the project: With Conan set up and the dependencies defined, you can now build your project. Run the appropriate build commands for your build system, ensuring that Conan is properly integrated into the build process.Resolve dependencies: During the build process, Conan will handle resolving and retrieving the necessary dependencies specified in your Conan recipe. It will download the required packages from the ConanCenter repository or other sources and make them available for your build.Test and run the program: Once the build process is complete, you can test and run your program. Ensure that all the necessary dependencies are properly linked and that your program functions as expected.By following these steps, you can leverage Conan and the ConanCenter repository to manage the dependencies for a complex C++ program like 3D Slicer. Keep in mind that the specific instructions may vary depending on your project's requirements, but these general guidelines should help you get started.",Solved

ERROR: Could not build wheels for llama-cpp-python, hnswlib, which is required to install pyproject.toml-based projects","The error message you mentioned suggests that the building of wheels for the packages ""llama-cpp-python"" and ""hnswlib"" failed, and these packages are required for installing pyproject.toml-based projects. To resolve this issue, you can try the following steps:Update system packages: Ensure that your Ubuntu system is up to date by running the following commands:[CODE_BLOCK_0]Install dependencies: Some packages require certain dependencies to be installed. Make sure you have the necessary dependencies by executing the following command:[CODE_BLOCK_1]Install Python development headers: Python development headers are often required for building certain packages. Install them with the following command:[CODE_BLOCK_2]Check package requirements: Verify that you have the necessary requirements for building the packages ""llama-cpp-python"" and ""hnswlib"". Refer to the documentation or README file of each package to ensure you have the required dependencies installed. Install any missing dependencies.Upgrade pip: Upgrade your pip package manager to the latest version by running:[CODE_BLOCK_3]Try installing the packages individually: Instead of installing the pyproject.toml-based project directly, attempt to install each problematic package separately to identify any additional errors or missing dependencies. 273,"how does omegle which uses webrtc detect if someone is using a vpn or proxy?

I am writing a research paper for my computer sciences masters.","Firstly, it's important to clarify that as of my knowledge cutoff in September 2021, Omegle does not explicitly state that it detects or blocks VPN or proxy usage. Many users report being able to use Omegle while connected through a VPN or proxy.However, let's explore the technical possibilities on how a service like Omegle could potentially identify VPN or proxy usage, using technologies like WebRTC:IP Address Database:

The simplest method to identify a VPN or proxy is by checking the user's IP address against a database of known VPN or proxy IP addresses. Commercial VPNs and proxies tend to use static or semi-static IP ranges, which can be identified and blacklisted. This method does not specifically involve WebRTC but could be used in conjunction with it.IP Address Inconsistencies:

WebRTC might leak a user's original IP address under certain circumstances, even when they're using a VPN or proxy. WebRTC relies on the Interactive Connectivity Establishment (ICE) protocol to set up the peer-to-peer connection. As part of this process, the client generates an ICE candidate list, which can include the user's private network IP and public-facing IP. If the VPN or proxy is not correctly configured to handle WebRTC traffic, the public-facing IP in the ICE candidate list might be the user's original IP rather than the VPN or proxy IP. If a service notices discrepancies between the IP associated with the user's connection and the IPs in the ICE candidate list, it could infer that the user is using a VPN or proxy.TCP/UDP Fingerprinting:

Advanced detection systems may infer the use of a VPN or proxy by analyzing traffic patterns. VPNs and proxies create unique traffic patterns due to their encapsulation and encryption protocols. However, these methods can be complex, resource-intensive, and not entirely accurate. As with the IP database method, this does not specifically involve WebRTC.Browser Fingerprinting:

A user might be identified by the unique combination of their browser and device characteristics, known as a browser fingerprint. This might include the list of installed fonts, screen resolution, browser version, etc. If a user connects with the same fingerprint but different IPs, a service could infer that they're using a VPN or proxy. This method is not completely reliable, as many characteristics can change over time or be deliberately obfuscated.DNS Leaks:

A poorly configured VPN might not handle DNS requests correctly, causing them to be sent outside of the VPN tunnel. If the service sees DNS requests coming from an IP different than the one associated with the user's connection, it might infer that the user is using a VPN or proxy. This method does not specifically involve WebRTC.Again, these methods are mostly speculative, and detecting VPN or proxy usage can be a complex and challenging task. There's also a balance to be struck between privacy considerations and the need to prevent misuse of the service. Note that the use of VPNs and proxies is a legitimate practice for many users who wish to protect their privacy, and not all services wish or need to block this usage.Lastly, it's worth mentioning that WebRTC is a versatile technology with many benefits, including the ability to create real-time, peer-to-peer connections in the browser, but it also has privacy implications that are still being explored and addressed. Therefore, your research paper can delve into these issues, discussing the challenges of privacy in real-time web communication.",Solved

277,How create an immutable map in Java ,"In Java, you can create an immutable map using the java.util.Collections class. The Collections class provides a method called unmodifiableMap() that takes a map as input and returns an unmodifiable (immutable) view of the map. Here's an example:[CODE_BLOCK_0]In the above example, we create a mutable map using HashMap, and then we pass it to Collections.unmodifiableMap() to obtain an immutable view of the map. Any attempt to modify the immutable map will result in an UnsupportedOperationException. However, the original mutable map can still be modified.Please note that the immutability of the map applies only to the map itself, not the objects it contains. If the map contains mutable objects, those objects can still be modified. To create a fully immutable map, you would need to make sure that the values in the map are also immutable or make defensive copies when adding objects to the map.",Unsolved

280,Im creating an nginx like webserv in c++ 98. The instructions say i have to give the option to turn on or off directory listing. What is this and how can i implement it,"Directory listing is a feature provided by many web servers that allows users to view the files and directories in the server's directory structure when they navigate to a directory that doesn't have an index file (like index.html or index.php).It's like a file explorer for your web server. It can be useful for file sharing, but it's usually not desirable for public-facing websites as it can expose internal files and structure to potential attackers.If you're creating a web server in C++, implementing this feature would involve checking whether directory listing is enabled when a request for a directory comes in. If it is enabled, and there's no index file in the directory, you would send a response containing a list of files and directories in that directory. If it's not enabled, you would send a 403 Forbidden or 404 Not Found response instead.Here is a simple outline of how you might go about implementing this feature:Configuration: Allow the server's operator to turn directory listing on or off. You could read this setting from a configuration file or command-line argument when the server starts. This value would be stored in a boolean variable, let's call it allowDirectoryListing.Request handling: When a GET request comes in, check if the requested path points to a directory. You can do this using the stat or opendir functions in the C++ standard library. If the path is not a directory, handle it as you would normally.Directory handling: If the requested path is a directory, check for an index file (like index.html or index.php). If an index file exists, serve that file. If not, check the value of allowDirectoryListing.Directory listing: If allowDirectoryListing is true, create a HTML document that contains a list of links to the files and directories in the requested directory. You can get this list using the readdir function. This HTML document is the response to the GET request. If allowDirectoryListing is false, respond with a 403 Forbidden or 404 Not Found status code instead.Remember that directory listing can expose sensitive data, so make sure it's only turned on when it's safe to do so. You might also want to add a way to exclude certain directories from directory listing, even when it's globally enabled.",Solved

285,I need help with helping me do some kind of a symlink in my Laravel app - I have a number of videos that are being uploaded to my storage/app/public folder - and my understanding is that I am able to somehow access these files from a URL - can you help me do this,"Yes, of course, I can assist you.To serve files from the storage directory in a Laravel application, the application uses a symbolic link (symlink) from public/storage to storage/app/public. This means when you access public/storage in your code, you're actually accessing storage/app/public.Here is a step-by-step guide on how to do this:Create the Symbolic LinkYou can create the symlink in Laravel using the storage:link artisan command. Open your terminal, navigate to your Laravel application's root directory, and run the following command:[CODE_BLOCK_0]This command will create a symlink from public/storage to storage/app/public. You should see a message like ""The [public/storage] directory has been linked."" if it's successful.Access the FilesNow, you can access the files in the storage/app/public directory as if they're in the public/storage directory. For instance, if you have a video file video.mp4 in storage/app/public, you can access it with a URL like this:[CODE_BLOCK_1]Store the FilesWhen storing the files, use the public disk (which corresponds to the storage/app/public directory). In Laravel, you can specify this when you use the store or storeAs methods. Here's an example:[CODE_BLOCK_2]This code will store the uploaded video file in the storage/app/public/videos directory. You can then access it at a URL like http://your-app-url/storage/videos/video.mp4.That's the basics of using the public disk and the symlink in Laravel. If you're having any issues or need more specific advice, don't hesitate to ask.",Solved

,"Thank you. I am having an issue with the Nova File Manager and specifically how it handles the s3 bucket - I have just tested and can confirm I am able to upload files to the bucket - but when I try to create a folder I get the following error:

[previous exception] [object] (GuzzleHttp\\Exception\\ClientException(code: 400): Client error: `PUT https://rent-roll-devour-bucket-a1.s3.ap-southeast-2.amazonaws.com/images/blog/folderrandomname/` resulted in a `400 Bad Request` response:

Can you help me troubleshoot","The error message you are getting indicates that the request you're making is not allowed according to the bucket's access control list (ACL). Specifically, the ""AccessControlListNotSupported"" code is often returned when you're trying to use an ACL-related operation on a bucket that has bucket policies or IAM policies in effect that block public access.Here are some steps to troubleshoot this issue:Check the ACL of your S3 bucket:Go to your AWS S3 dashboard, navigate to your bucket, go to the 'Permissions' tab and verify the bucket policy and the ACL. If there are any blocks on public access, you may want to revise this according to your needs.Check the IAM policy:If you're using an IAM user to access the bucket, make sure the user has the appropriate permissions to perform the operations. If necessary, you may need to update the IAM policy.Check the Nova File Manager configuration:Make sure you have correctly configured Nova File Manager to use S3 and the access credentials (like the access key, secret key, and bucket name) are correct.If after checking these points the problem persists, it might be helpful to post the relevant (anonymized) parts of your bucket policy, IAM policy, and Nova File Manager configuration so I can help you in a more specific way.Remember that it's crucial to avoid making your S3 bucket overly permissive in an attempt to solve the problem. Overly permissive buckets can be a security risk, so it's important to give only the minimum necessary permissions.If you're creating folders (which are just prefixes in S3 terminology) directly in your application, you might need to adjust the way you're doing it. S3 doesn't actually have physical directories, and what you might think of as a folder is actually just a prefix to the object's name. It's not necessary to ""create a folder"" before storing an object with a prefix. If your application or library is attempting to do an operation that isn't supported with the S3 API, such as creating a directory like it would on a local filesystem, it might cause errors.",
,"Please find date below and help me based on this info. My Permission's Bucket Policy is:
Grant basic read/write permissions to other AWS accounts. Learn more
This bucket has the bucket owner enforced setting applied for Object Ownership
When bucket owner enforced is applied, use bucket policies to control access. Learn more
Authenticated users group (anyone with an AWS account)

]","Based on the information provided, your bucket's policy and ACL seem to be in order. You have allowed public read access to the objects in your bucket which should be sufficient for retrieving the objects. However, the error message you're receiving typically indicates an issue with writing operations to the bucket.In your bucket policy, you only have read permissions (""s3:GetObject"", ""s3:GetObjectVersion"") specified. If you're trying to create a folder (or in S3 terms, upload an object with a key that ends in a slash to create the illusion of a folder), you would need write permissions as well.Try extending your bucket policy to include write permissions such as ""s3:PutObject"". Here's an example of how to modify your existing policy:[CODE_BLOCK_0]This policy will give write access to anyone on the internet. If you're using an IAM user for your Laravel application, you should specify that IAM user's ARN in the ""Principal"" field instead of ""*"" to ensure that only your application has write access.Also, please be aware that providing s3:PutObject for ""*"" might be a significant security risk because it allows anyone to upload files to your bucket. Therefore, it is recommended to restrict this policy to specific IAM users or roles that require this permission.Remember to review your AWS S3 settings as the AWS Management Console UI might have changed since my training cut-off in September 2021.Lastly, ensure that your Laravel code and the Nova File Manager package are correctly configured to use S3 and that the AWS SDK (which Laravel uses under the hood to interact with S3) is up-to-date.",

It might be possible that the missing library is a result of some broken dependencies or some recent updates. Try to see if there are any pending upgrades or fixes:[CODE_BLOCK_3]Verify Bit Architecture:

Ensure that the library's architecture (32-bit or 64-bit) matches the architecture of your Python environment. Installing a 32-bit library when you're running a 64-bit Python, or vice versa, can lead to these types of issues.Reboot:

Sometimes, a simple reboot can resolve library path issues, especially after installing new packages or making changes to system configurations.If you follow these steps and still encounter issues, you might need to provide more context about your setup (like the specific Python program you're running, any other error messages, etc.) for more detailed troubleshooting.",Unsolved

288,"The `websocat` program has a number of options. In particular it has the `--jsonrpc`, how should I use this?","As of my knowledge cutoff in September 2021, the specifics of the --jsonrpc option in websocat are not directly documented. websocat is a command-line web socket client and server, and it's often used for testing, debugging, and generally interacting with websockets from a terminal.--jsonrpc option would likely indicate that the tool is capable of interacting with JSON-RPC services. JSON-RPC is a remote procedure call (RPC) protocol encoded in JSON.However, the exact semantics of the --jsonrpc option would depend on the specifics of the websocat version you're using, and since that detail is not documented as of my last training data in 2021, it's best to consult the latest documentation or use the --help option directly with the program to get more detailed and updated information.To do so, open your terminal and type:[CODE_BLOCK_0]If you want to try to use --jsonrpc, it's probably used along with a WebSocket URL that points to a JSON-RPC service. For example:[CODE_BLOCK_1]Remember to replace ws://example.com/jsonrpc with your actual JSON-RPC WebSocket endpoint.If you can't find satisfactory details via these means, consider reaching out to the developers or the community around websocat for more specific help.",Unsolved

,"When using websocat, there's an option called `--basic-auth`, it says it adds an `Auhtorization: Basic` HTTP request header. Why would there be a HTTP request header for websocket communication?","The WebSocket protocol is a computer communications protocol, providing full-duplex communication channels over a single TCP connection. However, the WebSocket protocol doesn't exist independently
column2: rather, it is initiated by making an HTTP request with an Upgrade: websocket header, signaling that the client wants to establish a WebSocket connection.This is where the --basic-auth option in websocat comes in. When you're making the initial HTTP request to establish a WebSocket connection, you may need to provide authentication details. The --basic-auth option allows you to add an Authorization: Basic HTTP request header with your username and password, which is then base64 encoded.Here is an example of how to use it:[CODE_BLOCK_0]Replace username:password with your actual username and password, and ws://example.com with your WebSocket URL.This basic auth header will be included in the initial HTTP upgrade request sent to the server. If the server requires basic authentication and the provided credentials are correct, the server will switch the protocol from HTTP to WebSocket, otherwise the WebSocket connection will not be established.It's important to note that basic authentication sends credentials in an encoded form, but not encrypted. Therefore, it's not secure against eavesdropping or man-in-the-middle attacks unless used in conjunction with a secure transport layer like HTTPS (i.e., wss:// for secure WebSocket connections).",

column1: ,"So in order to establish a websocket connection, you must always have an initial HTTP request message?","Yes, you're correct. The process to establish a WebSocket connection starts with an HTTP request, specifically an HTTP GET request that includes an ""Upgrade: websocket"" header. This is often referred to as the WebSocket handshake request.The client sends this initial HTTP request to the server, requesting to upgrade the connection to a WebSocket. The request might look something like this:[CODE_BLOCK_0]If the server supports the WebSocket protocol, it agrees to the upgrade and replies with an HTTP 101 status code (Switching Protocols), something like this:[CODE_BLOCK_1]After this handshake process, the connection is upgraded from HTTP to a WebSocket connection, and data can be sent as WebSocket frames, in both directions, between client and server.This handshake process is necessary because it allows servers to handle both WebSocket and HTTP traffic on the same URL or port, which is especially useful if you want to add real-time features (which WebSockets are great for) to an existing HTTP-based application. It's also an integral part of the WebSocket protocol as defined in its specification.",

,"The same TCP connection that responds with HTTP 101 status code, is it preserved for the websocket connection afterwards?","Yes, exactly. The TCP connection used for the initial HTTP request and response is the same one that's used for the subsequent WebSocket communication. This is why it's said that WebSocket ""upgrades"" the connection rather than establishing a new one.Once the client sends the HTTP GET request with the Upgrade: websocket header, and the server agrees to the upgrade by responding with the HTTP 101 status code, the protocol being used on that TCP connection changes from HTTP to WebSocket. The connection then remains open for full-duplex communication, allowing both the client and server to send and receive data at any time.This is part of what makes WebSocket particularly effective for real-time, bidirectional communication between client and server. Unlike with HTTP, where a new TCP connection must be established for each request (or at least each series of requests in HTTP/1.1 with keep-alive connections), WebSocket keeps the connection open for as long as the client and server need to communicate. This reduces overhead and makes communication more efficient.",

,"Does this mean authentication headers like tokens that authenticate a websocket connection should be done in the HTTP request response handshake, before websocket messages are exchanged, or after the websocket connection is established?","Yes, any authentication required for a WebSocket connection should take place during the initial HTTP handshake process, before the connection is upgraded to a WebSocket connection. This is because once the WebSocket connection is established, it no longer uses the HTTP protocol and headers like Authorization cannot be sent.So, if your server requires authentication for WebSocket connections, that authentication should take place during the HTTP handshake. This might involve including an Authorization header with a token in the handshake request, or perhaps sending a token as a query parameter or cookie. How this is done will depend on your server and application requirements.For example, you could include a token in the WebSocket URL like this:[CODE_BLOCK_0]Or use the --header option in websocat to add an Authorization header:[CODE_BLOCK_1]Keep in mind that if the WebSocket connection is not over a secure (WSS) connection, this could expose your token to eavesdroppers. Always use secure WebSocket connections (WSS, similar to HTTPS) when dealing with sensitive information like tokens.Remember, once the WebSocket connection is established, you cannot send HTTP headers anymore, and will need to handle any further ""authentication"" at the application level, by including necessary data in the WebSocket messages themselves.",

,"After receiving the HTTP 101, what does the client send after that? Can you give me a on-the-wire example? Is it text-formatted or in binary?","After the HTTP 101 Switching Protocols response from the server, the protocol on the connection switches from HTTP to WebSocket. From this point on, both the client and server can send WebSocket data frames back and forth on the same connection.The WebSocket protocol defines both text and binary frames, so the client can send either type. The contents of the frame depend on the application-level protocol being used on top of WebSocket.Here's a simplified example of what might be sent on the wire from the client to the server, using a text frame:[CODE_BLOCK_0]Explanation:FIN=1: This is the final fragment of this message (WebSocket supports fragmentation, but this message only has one fragment)Opcode=1: This is a text frameMASK=1: This frame is masked (client-to-server frames must be masked according to the WebSocket protocol)Payload_len=5: The payload data is 5 bytes longMasking_key=0x37FA2135: The masking key used to encode the payload dataPayload=""Hello"": The payload data, ""Hello"", which has been masked by XORing with the masking keyOn the wire, this is sent as binary data. The 81 85 37 FA 21 35 7F 9F 4D 34 bytes correspond to the above frame fields.For example, 81 in binary is 10000001, where the first bit is FIN, the next three bits are reserved (and should be 0 unless an extension defines their meaning), and the last four bits are the Opcode. 85 is Payload_len with the mask bit set, and so on.This is a very simplified example. In a real-world application, there might be additional considerations, like using extensions for compression, dealing with fragmentation if messages are large, and so on. Also, the masking process is a bit more involved, but this gives you a general idea of how it works.The actual content of the WebSocket frames you send and receive would be determined by the application protocol you're using on top of WebSocket. For example, if you're using a chat application, you might send JSON-encoded messages with fields for the user ID, timestamp, message text, and so on.",

,"So on the wire, the websocket frames are always binary encoded? You mention text frames and binary frames? What does this mean? Is this specifically regarding the payload of the websocket frame, even though the frame itself is always binary?","Yes, you've got it right. When we talk about WebSocket ""frames,"" we're discussing a specific structure outlined by the WebSocket protocol, and this structure is always binary on the wire.When we refer to ""text frames"" and ""binary frames,"" we're speaking about the nature of the payload data carried within the frame structure.In the context of WebSockets:A text frame carries payload data intended to be interpreted as UTF-8 encoded text.A binary frame carries payload data intended to be interpreted as binary data.So when a text frame is sent, the payload of the frame is text, but it's sent as binary data on the wire since it's UTF-8 encoded. The distinction between text and binary frames allows the receiver to correctly interpret the payload data.The initial byte of a WebSocket frame contains an opcode that indicates the frame type. For instance, an opcode of 0x1 indicates a text frame, while an opcode of 0x2 denotes a binary frame.To sum up, regardless of whether you're sending a text or binary frame, the entire WebSocket frame, including the payload, is represented as binary data on the wire. The ""text"" or ""binary"" classification refers to how the payload data should be interpreted by the receiving end.",

,Is there space to send metadata on the websocket frame?,"The WebSocket frame structure itself does not provide a designated place for metadata beyond the essentials required for the WebSocket protocol operation, such as the opcode indicating the frame type (text, binary, etc.), payload length, masking key for client-to-server messages, and so on.If your application needs to send metadata along with the payload data, you will typically have to include it within the payload data itself. The exact method for doing this depends on your application-level protocol.For example, if you're sending text frames and your application-level protocol uses JSON, you might structure your payload something like this:[CODE_BLOCK_0]In this example, the ""metadata"" and ""data"" are both part of the payload data for a text frame. When you send this message, it would be serialized to a JSON string, UTF-8 encoded to get binary data, and that binary data would be the payload for the WebSocket text frame.If you're sending binary data, you'd have to come up with a binary format that includes both your metadata and payload. The specifics of how to do this would depend heavily on the requirements of your application.Remember that all of this data is application-specific. The WebSocket protocol itself doesn't understand your metadata or payload data
column2: it just provides a way for you to send binary or text data back and forth between a client and server.",

column1: ,"In what situations would it make sense to have a second level of authentication in the payload itself? Suppose we were using JSONRPC as the payload protocol, then inside JSONRPC we may store tokens for authentication there.","In many situations, the initial authentication during the WebSocket handshake is enough. Once the connection is established, you're typically communicating in a closed, authenticated session.However, there can be situations where an additional level of authentication in the payload can be useful:Fine-grained access control: In some cases, different types of operations may require different permissions. For example, a user might have permission to read data but not to write data. By including a token in each request, the server can verify the permissions for each individual operation, not just the connection as a whole.Multi-user authentication: If you have a scenario where the client acts on behalf of multiple users (e.g., in a proxy situation or a client that handles operations for multiple users simultaneously), the client could use different tokens for different operations to act on behalf of different users on the same WebSocket connection.Long-lived WebSocket connections: For security reasons, it's common for authentication tokens to have an expiration time, after which they're no longer valid. If you have a WebSocket connection that stays open for a long time, it's possible the token could expire during that time. By including a token in each request, the client can refresh the token when needed without having to close and re-open the WebSocket connection.If you're using JSON-RPC or a similar protocol over WebSocket, you could include a token in the params of each request. Here's an example of how you might do this with JSON-RPC:[CODE_BLOCK_0]In this example, the getMessages method requires a token parameter for authentication. The server would need to check this token and verify that it's valid and has the necessary permissions for each individual JSON-RPC request.Remember that all security measures should be carefully considered and appropriately applied according to your application's needs. Always use secure WebSocket connections (WSS, similar to HTTPS) when dealing with sensitive information like tokens.",

,"Because websockets sit on of an HTTP transaction, that means there's always a potential MTLS authentication before an HTTP request can be sent, which enables another layer of authentication, and finally the payload protocol could have its own authentication.","Absolutely correct. As you mentioned, these multiple layers can provide additional security:Mutual TLS (mTLS): This is a protocol that provides transport-level security, where both the client and server are authenticated to each other. mTLS, also known as client certificate authentication, uses certificates to verify the identity of both parties before a connection is established.HTTP-level authentication: During the initial HTTP handshake that sets up the WebSocket connection, you can use standard HTTP authentication methods, like the Authorization header or cookie-based authentication.Payload-level authentication: After the WebSocket connection is established, you can include authentication data (like tokens) in the payload of the WebSocket messages. This would be part of your application-level protocol (like JSON-RPC, as you mentioned) on top of WebSocket.It's important to note that each of these layers serves a different purpose and they can be used together for enhanced security.mTLS provides a strong guarantee that the connection is being made by a known, trusted client and to a known, trusted server.HTTP-level authentication is used to authenticate the user to the server.Payload-level authentication can be used for fine-grained access control on individual operations, multi-user scenarios, or handling token expiration in long-lived connections.While it's possible to use all of these methods together, whether or not you should depends on the specific requirements and threat model of your application. Each layer of authentication introduces additional complexity, so it's important to balance security needs with the added complexity and potential performance impact.",

289,Does vscode start a new language server for each vscode window or is the language server shared between windows? Whats the common practice?,"The behavior of the Language Server Protocol (LSP) in Visual Studio Code can depend on the specific language server implementation and how it's integrated with the editor. However, generally:One Language Server per VS Code Window: In most cases, a new instance of a language server is started for each VS Code window. This ensures that the state, analysis, and resources for one project (or window) do not interfere with another.Isolation: The reason for the above approach is to keep things isolated. If you have multiple projects open in separate windows, and one project causes the language server to crash or hang, it won't affect the other projects.Configuration Differences: Different windows can have different workspace settings, and therefore, might require different configurations for the language server. Having separate instances ensures that each server is configured correctly for its respective window.Shared Servers: Some language servers might be designed to be shared across multiple clients or editors. This is less common and might be relevant for more heavyweight servers that are expensive to start or that maintain a large shared cache. However, even in this case, the shared instance would still need to manage separate contexts for each client to avoid conflicts and ensure correct behavior.Performance Considerations: While starting a separate language server for each window can have memory and CPU overhead, for many languages and projects, this overhead is minimal compared to the convenience and stability it provides. However, if you're opening many VS Code windows, you might notice more resource usage.In summary, the common practice for many language servers in VS Code is to start a new server for each window, providing isolation and ensuring proper behavior for each project or workspace. However, the exact behavior can vary based on the language server's design and integration with the editor.",Solved
291,"Write a GitHub Actions workflow implementing the following:
Every time a new release is released the workflow updates thatbranch to exactly match the tag that was just released

Any time a commit to main includes the text ""!stable-docs"" all changes to docs/ in that commit should be made available in the stable-docs branch too.","Certainly! Here's a GitHub Actions workflow that accomplishes your requirements:On new release: The workflow updates the stable-docs branch to match the tag of the released version.On a commit to main with the text !stable-docs: The workflow checks for changes in the docs/ directory in that commit and applies those changes to the stable-docs branch.Here's the yml file for the workflow:[CODE_BLOCK_0]A few notes on this workflow:We're checking out the repository using actions/checkout@v2.We're setting up a Git user to make commits as the GitHub Actions Bot (or any name/email you prefer).For the release event, we're resetting the stable-docs branch to the exact commit of the release tag and then force pushing it to make sure it matches.For the commit to main, we're using git diff-tree to get a list of files changed in the docs/ directory. If there are changes, we switch to the stable-docs branch, check out only those changes, commit them, and then push to the stable-docs branch.You can place this YAML code in the .github/workflows directory of your repository, in a file named, say, update_stable_docs.yml.Remember to replace <your-email@example.com> with your email or any email you'd like the bot to use.",Solved
